comment.author: 18885703@N00
comment._content:
I was on Clare Island in 1979, the week after the disastrous Fastnet Race, looking across to the lighthouse on a perfectly still day: I wrote

Over the dazzle of the water,
Fastnet is a finger held high
for a breeze that isn't blowing.

..which doesn't help dating; nice pic, though!

comment.author: 7923708@N07
comment._content: Beautiful!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: It looks a hive of industry in spite of the chop on the water.  When you see these constructions you realise the wonder of the engineering and navvying that went into them and also the motivation behind them.  A sign of our humanity in its best sense for a change.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
From the (almost) infallible Wikipedia!
In 1891 the Commissioners of Irish Lights had resolved that the light was not sufficiently powerful, particularly for the first landfall for many ships crossing the Atlantic. The replacement was constructed of stone, cast iron now being considered unsatisfactory — the whole of the nearby Calf tower above its strengthening casing had been carried away during a gale on 27 November 1881, although without loss of life. On the same day, the sea had broken the glass of the Fastnet Rock lantern.

The new lighthouse was designed by William Douglass and built under the supervision of James Kavanagh. Construction started in 1897 with the levelling of the site, and the first of 2,047 Cornish granite dovetailed blocks was laid in June 1899.

The new lighthouse entered service on 27 June 1904 having cost nearly £90,000.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: From my examination of this it looks as though it was fairly close to completion!  There are no derricks/cranes on the upper levels indicating that the heavy liftting and movement of materials has finished.  The lighthouse tower looks complete and there appears to be a lot of the machinery in situ which would seem to me that it is in the latter stages of construction.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] You could be right but you would not see it from the angle that the shot above was taken from.  It had to rise quite a distance to be seen from that angle.  See Wendys shot from this angle [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lizinitaly/7969411156/in/set-72157631495163732]  I did notify her that I was making these links and she is quite happy to have them used for comparison!
I think that what is quite clear is that the original cast iron lighthouse is still in situ with its related equipment and the new LH is still in the early stages at the very least!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Two construction photos. Today's view is a bit different, as that big concrete store was added in 1969 to provide a helicopter landing pad.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Those were DOVETAILED granite blocks!  Imagine the precision cutting involved for the male and female versions with the external and internal curves so precise?  Fantastic workmanship - the Stonemasons art at it's pinnacle of perfection!
Looking at those two photographs of yours it would appear that the construction was at most just begun when the shot was taken as the derrick inside the tower is not in evidence in the shot and it would most likely have been.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From Mizen head Visitor Centre, J. Kavanagh, son of the foreman, proceeded with the plumber and four men to dismantle the old tower in March 1904.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] From that Visitor Centre page: The stones were cut with dovetail joints in all directions to interlock and give strength to the tower. No stone can be removed unless all stones are removed from above it. This system of dovetail toggles bonds the entire structure into a monolith. The entire tower was erected in sections of 6 – 8 courses in the contractor’s yard in Cornwall where Mr. Douglass or Mr. Foot, the Resident Engineer, inspected them before they were dismantled and transported to Rock Island. They were checked rigorously at the Rock Island yard again before they were transported on the ‘Ierne’ to the Fastnet Rock.

comment._content:
This photo (from the Cork Examiner 1974) shows how they used to use those cranes to hoist people and blocks of granite to and from the rock - extremely dodgy!  It also shows that there was / is a level-ish track round to the new lighthouse site on the other (north?) side.  Which implies that the large dock wall and track was built first to enable construction of the second lighthouse.  Or not? 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/chartrouse/8136205782/]

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: By shear coincidence a colleague of mine happens to have James Morrissey's book "A History of the Fastnet Lighthouse" on his desk. It includes a photograph almost exactly the same* as this one with the following caption: "The derricks, on right, in place for off-loading materials and equipment for the construction work on the new tower, which was well underway in 1899" (*the photo in the book is from exactly the same angle with exactly the same land & building features but some of the wave patterns are different - it must have been taken just before or just after this one.)

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Here's a bit more history of the lighthouse www.economist.com/node/12792727 "Meticulous to a fault, Douglass ordered the contractors to assemble the tower in sections first in their Cornish yard, to ensure that not a stone was out of place. Each rock was to be delicately wrapped and shipped to Ireland."

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The construction of the new lighthouse featured on the front cover of Scientific American magazine in 1907. The photo shows both lighthouses on the rock together before the old one was demolished.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Now that would be a nice one to have!

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
I can't  comment much on the photo, but I've had an instructive interlude scanning the 3317 occurrences of 'Fastnet' in the London Times between 1847 (the loss of the Stephen Whitney, which caused the first lighthouse to be built), and 2006.

What I hadn't previously realised was that because of its position, the Fastnet had another role (apart from acting as a warning of dangerous rocks). For transatlantic shipping it was the first sight of land, and from about 1870 news of shipping passing the Fastnet was relayed to London and published in the newspapers, this being aided in the early years of the 20th century by wireless communication.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: So I guess we're looking at a shot taken between 1897 and 1904 but most likely between 1897 and 1899 with the caveat that it just might have been as late as 1900;-)

This photo seems to have generated huge interest.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] I'm at one with Carol WOW!  Those close ups of the construction are really interesting.  The care being taken of each block so the edges or dovetailing is not damaged, the protection of the blocks in situ when the new blocks are being raised and the male and female dovetailing on the blocks is clear for all to see!  Well done at finding them!
